awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Workshop to Develop a Roadmap for Greater Public Use of Privacy-Sensitive Government Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent events have shown the value of better data sharing; the rapidity of change in COVID-19 and the difficulty of coordinating response is a clear example. At the same time, public concern over privacy is increasing, making it more difficult to collect reliable data.  Improved use of government data by a wide range of users has potential to improve research as well as day-to-day operations at a variety of levels, from local to national and global.  Government data can also foster innovation, providing opportunities for small companies based on large-scale data analysis that are increasingly reserved for large organizations capable of gathering their own data (often in ways that raise privacy concerns). We are running a 2-day workshop to identify challenges and explore mechanisms (technical, legal, and procedural) to enable greater use of privacy-sensitive data held by government agencies.

Privacy technology has experienced great advances over the past decade.  Breakthroughs such as fully homomorphic encryption, differential privacy, and advances in secure multiparty computation have great promise to enable broader public use of data, while maintaining individual privacy.  While there have been some successes, there are many applications where there is a significant gap between what technology offers, data needs of users, and policies and procedures to ensure privacy.  This includes best practices as well as research and policy challenges that limit effective use of data. This workshop explores these concerns, highlighting new research challenges based on actual user needs for government data.  This covers research in underlying technologies that address real-world challenges, as well as research in policy to enable use of technology in ways that provide appropriate levels of protection for privacy-sensitive data. The outcome will be a report identifying unmet needs of data users, issues limiting broader use of government data, and technologies and policies that show promise of bridging these gaps. This will serve as a roadmap for research investment to address these challenges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Agent-based models (ABMs) are a promising tool to simulate complex systems, such as pandemics. Their utility depends upon the ability to recreate populations with great detail, efficiently calibrate to real-world data and analyze sensitivity of results. However, ABMs are conventionally slow to execute, difficult to scale to large populations and tough to calibrate. We aim to alleviate these challenges by fundamentally rethinking ABMs in this era of AI. Our research introduces GradABM: a scalable, differentiable ABM design that is amenable to gradient-based learning with automatic differentiation. GradABMs can simulate million-size populations in a few seconds on commodity hardware, integrate with deep neural networks and ingest heterogeneous data sources. With this grant, our work has demonstrated benefits of GradABM for quickly scaling simulations to million-size populations, enabling data-driven and robust calibration (by coupling with neural networks) [1] and with uncertainty quantification (via generative neural modeling) [2] as well as efficient validation using gradient-based sensitivity analyses [3]. We have demonstrated these computational advances through real-world epidemiological simulations of COVID-19 on massachusetts (8 million agents) and UK (60 million agents).Here, GradABMs have enabled global health institutions to design prospective interventions (eg: vaccination protocols [4]) as well as evaluate impact of retrospective interventions (eg: seroprevalence from lockdown protocols [3]). More recently, we have also introduced AgentTorch [5], an open-source platform for building custom GradABMs across digital, physical and biological realms. This will enable domain experts - epidemiologists, immunologists, economists etc - to rapidly iterate and benefit from the capabilities of AI and ABMs, while abstracted from the engineering complexity. We continue to pursue projects to advance the computational abilities of GradABMs: focusing on enabling more private and decentralized simulations in the real-world; and are also actively engaging with global policy institutions to ensure the benefits of such simulations can be realized for low-middle income countries.

[1]: Differentiable Agent-based Epidemiology. AAMAS 2023

[2]: Bayesian calibration of differentiable agent-based models. ICLR Workshop 2023

[3]: Don’t Simulate Twice:One-shot sensitivity analyses via Automatic Differentiation. AAMAS 2023

[4]: Using Neural Networks to Calibrate Agent Based Models Enables Improved Regional Evidence for Vaccine Strategy and Policy. Vaccine 2023

[5]: AgentTorch: agent-based modeling with automatic differentiation. arxiv 2023. (Currently Under-review)


Last Modified: 08/31/2023
Modified by: Ramesh Raskar
